anchor.surface_text: The requirements of Art. 311 2  have been companysidered by this Court on several occasions. At the relevant time, Art. 311 2  provided that numberperson to whom Art. 311 applies shall be dismissed or removed or reduced in rank until he has been given a reasonable opportunity of showing cause against the action proposed to be taken in regard t9 him.

concepts.interpretation: No civil servant shall be dismissed, removed or reduced in rank without reasonable opportunity of showing cause.

anchor.surface_text: This question falls to be companysidered on the companystruction of rule 55 of the Civil Services  Classification, Control and Appeal  Rules. This rule reads thus- Without prejudice to the provisions of the Public Servants Inquiries Act, 1850, numberorder of dismissal, removal or reduction shall be passed on a member of a service  other than an order based on facts which have led to the companyviction in a Criminal Court or by a Court, Martial  unless he has been informed in writing of the grounds on which it is proposed to take action, and. has been afforded an adequate opportunity of defending himself. The grounds on which it is proposed to take action shall be reduced to the form of a definite charge or charges, which shall be companymunicated to the person charged together with a statement of the allegations on which each. charge is based and of any other circumstances which it is proposed to take into companysideration in passing orders on the case. He shall be required within a reasonable time, to put in a written statement of his defence and to state whether he desires to be heard in person. If he so desires or if the authority companycerned so direct, an oral enquiry shall be held. At that enquiry oral evidence shall be heard as to such of the allegations as are number admitted, and the person charged shall be entitled to cross-examine the witnesses, to give evidence in person and to have such witnesses called. as he may wish, provided that the officer companyducting the enquiry may, for special and sufficient reason to be recorded in writing. refuse to call a witness. The proceedings shall companytain a sufficient record of the evidence and a statement of the findings and the grounds thereof.

concepts.interpretation: Mandates oral enquiry if charge-sheeted officer desires to be heard in person or authority directs; entitles to cross-examine, give evidence, call witnesses (with exceptions for special reasons).

issues.text: The short question of law which arises in this appeal is whether the appellant had given a reasonable opportunity to the respondent to defend himself before it passed the final order compulsorily retiring him under Article 353 of the Civil Service Regulations.

anchor.surface_text: The short question of law which arises in this appeal is whether the appellant, the State of Bombay  number Maharashtra , shows that its predecessor State of Madhya Pradesh  hereinafter called the Government  had given a reasonable opportunity to. the respondent, Narul Latif Khan, to defend himself before it passed the final order on June 6, 1952 companypulsorily retiring him under Article 353 of the Civil Service Regulations.

arguments.claim: Rule 55 mandates oral enquiry if charge-sheeted officer desires to be heard in person or authority directs; failure violates reasonable opportunity under Art. 311.

anchor.surface_text: This question falls to be companysidered on the companystruction of rule 55 of the Civil Services  Classification, Control and Appeal  Rules. This rule reads thus- Without prejudice to the provisions of the Public Servants Inquiries Act, 1850, numberorder of dismissal, removal or reduction shall be passed on a member of a service  other than an order based on facts which have led to the companyviction in a Criminal Court or by a Court, Martial  unless he has been informed in writing of the grounds on which it is proposed to take action,

arguments.claim: Respondent desired oral enquiry to examine doctors, but Mr. Mehta did not hold it despite insistence.

anchor.surface_text: We have carefully examined the record in this case and we see numberjustification for assuming that the respondent at any time gave up his demand for an oral enquiry in the sense that he should be given permission to cite his doctors in support of his pica that his failure to resume his duties was due to his ill-health.

arguments.claim: Oral enquiry requirement under Rule 55 is mandatory, based on natural justice; essential to allow leading own evidence.

anchor.surface_text: Indeed. this requirement is plainly based upon companysiderations of natural justice and fairplay. If the charge-sheeted officer wants to lead his own evidence in support of his plea, it is obviously essential that he should be given an opportunity to lead such evidence.

arguments.claim: Government can rely solely on documents for its case, no obligation to examine witnesses.

anchor.surface_text: We will assume for the purpose of this appeal that in a given case, Government would be justified in placing its case against the charge- sheeted officer only on documents and may be under numberobligation to examine any witnesses,

arguments.claim: Respondent's doctors' evidence would be relevant to show disobedience not deliberate due to illness.

anchor.surface_text: The charge against him was that he had deliberately disobeyed the Government orders, and it is companyceivable that this charge companyld have been met by the respondent by showing that though he disobeyed the orders, the disobedience was in numbersense deliberate because his doctors had advised him to lie in bed

anchor.surface_text: But it is clear from the remarks made by Mr. Mehta in the order sheet on September 21, 1951, and the observations made by him in his report that the only point on which the respondent agreed with Mr. Mehta was that he need number be allowed the assistance of the lawyer in the departmental enquiry.

holdings.text: The impugned order of compulsory retirement is invalid as it contravenes Article 311(2) because the respondent was not given a reasonable opportunity to defend himself.

anchor.surface_text: That is how the main question which falls for our decision is whether the constitutional provision prescribed by Art. 311 has been complied with by the appellant before it passed the impugned order. At this stage, it may be relevant to refer to some material facts.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Departmental enquiry held without mandatory oral enquiry despite respondent's demand violates Rule 55 and natural justice principles under Art. 311(2).

holdings.text: The failure to hold an oral enquiry by the enquiry officer amounts to a failure to provide reasonable opportunity under Article 311(2).

anchor.surface_text: Therefore, the position is that Mr. Mehta did net hold an oral enquiry and did number give an opportunity to the respondent to examine his witnesses and so, the question which arises for our decision is does the failure of Mr. Mehta to hold an oral enquiry amount to a failure to give a reasonable opportunity to the respondent within the meaning of Art. 311 ?

holdings.reasoning_summary: Respondent insisted on examining doctors for his defense; enquiry officer did not hold oral enquiry as required by Rule 55.

holdings.text: It was obligatory on the enquiry officer to hold an oral enquiry and allow the respondent to lead oral evidence and examine his doctors.

anchor.surface_text: So, the narrow question to which we must address ourselves is whether it was obligatory on Mr. Mehta to hold, an oral enquiry and give d reasonable opportunity to the respondent to lead oral evidence and examine his doctors.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Rule 55 mandates oral enquiry if officer desires to be heard in person; respondent did not waive demand.

holdings.text: Rule 55 makes it obligatory on the Enquiry Officer to hold an oral enquiry and give the respondent a chance to examine his witnesses if demanded.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Plain text of Rule 55 uses 'shall be held' if officer desires or authority directs; independent of government's evidence.

holdings.text: The requirement under Rule 55 for holding an oral enquiry if the charge-sheeted officer so desires is mandatory.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Uses mandatory 'shall'; founded on natural justice requiring opportunity to lead evidence.

holdings.text: Once the respondent desired to lead evidence, it was obligatory on the enquiry officer to fix a date for oral evidence.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Respondent's medical evidence relevant to defense of non-deliberate disobedience; no waiver found.

holdings.text: The respondent did not give up his demand for oral enquiry to examine doctors.

anchor.surface_text: We have carefully examined the record in this case and we see numberjustification for assuming that the respondent at any time gave up his demand for an oral enquiry in the sense that he should be given permission to cite his doctors in support of his pica that his failure to resume his duties was due to his ill-health.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Record shows consistent insistence despite agreement on no counsel needed.

holdings.text: Compulsory retirement under Article 353 attracts Article 311(2).

anchor.surface_text: It is common ground that the impugned order of compulsory retirement attracts the provisions of Art. 311(2).

holdings.reasoning_summary: Common ground between parties; reduction in rank or equivalent.

holdings.text: If relevant rule mandates oral enquiry on demand, failure constitutes violation of reasonable opportunity under Art. 311(2).

anchor.surface_text: This position is number disputed by the learned Attorney-General and is indeed well-settled.

holdings.text: It is unnecessary to consider defects in second notice and final order as enquiry already fatally infirm.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Single fatal infirmity sufficient to invalidate.

holdings.text: Validity of impugned order judged objectively without considering impropriety of respondent's language or reluctance to appear.

anchor.surface_text: The validity of the impugned order must be judged objectively without considering the impropriety of the language used by the respondent or the reluctance shown by him to appear before Mr. Mehta.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Procedural compliance assessed independently of conduct.
